Specific Details: Probate office delays
DPOs Lobbied: Colm Brophy|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Probate office delays
Intended Results: An improvement in the service delivered by the probate office to applicants
Lobbying Activities: Royal London (Ireland) believes the Irish public are being negatively impacted by the length and complexity of the probate system in Ireland, and that this is having a direct impact on the financial position of beneficiaries who are primary dependants of the deceased. It has created a position paper which presents an insight into the current workings of probate services in both the UK and Ireland which provides a comparative analysis between the two jurisdictions and identifies five key recommendations for change for the Irish probate system.|Email|6-10

Specific Details: Introductory meeting with Minister Colm Brophy TD to discuss Crosscare Migrant Project's work; client work, research, policy and networking work as it relates to Irish migrants returning to and leaving Ireland, sometimes in crisis situations. Also discussed in light of the Covid-19 pandemic; the Irish diaspora, diaspora policy, Emigrant Support Programme Organisations, Local Authorities, homelessness and North South matters.
DPOs Lobbied: Colm Brophy|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Introductory meeting with Minister Colm Brophy TD to discuss Crosscare Migrant Project's work; client work, research, policy and networking work as it relates to Irish migrants returning to and leaving Ireland, sometimes in crisis situations. Also discussed in light of the Covid-19 pandemic; the Irish diaspora, diaspora policy, Emigrant Support Programme Organisations, Local Authorities, homelessness and North South matters.
Intended Results: Supporting Irish migrants abroad and returning to Ireland. We have had success in supporting clients (e.g. our work with Consular through the pandemic) but it has exposed weaknesses in statutory services’ system and a failure to develop an effective protocol to manage crisis returns, particularly for people with complex support needs.::Diaspora needs are still not embedded within Departmental or cross-Departmental policies and an unforeseen event such as the Covid-19 pandemic gives us some learning about what gaps leave us exposed in our response to support Irish citizens returning in crisis e.g 1.Barriers to return including housing/homeless and self-isolation during Covid, 2. HRC – still an issue with lack of consistency in decision making  and potential to increase with more returnees, 3. Issues with non-EU family members
Lobbying Activities: Virtual meeting of approximately 1 hour between Minister Brophy's office and Crosscare Migrant Project team (working from home) on the Webex platform.|Virtual Meeting|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Mr Richard King, Project Leader, Crosscare Migrant Project

Specific Details: Calling on the Irish Government to participate in the 2022 Global Disability summit and to: 1 Demonstrate strong effective leadership by sending high-level representatives to the Summit; 2 Make ambitious, measurable and actionable commitments that are fully resourced and focus on neglected areas, particularly the rights of women and girls; 3 Ensure people with disabilities and their representative organisations are involved in the development of their countries’ commitments.

Intended Results: To ensure participation of the Irish Government in the global Disability Summit and obtain commitments from governments to implement changes to equality & disability legislation.

Specific Details: We spoke about foreign policy pertaining to Irish Aid support of Cambodia informing the DPO of our work in educational change and the need for a policy shift to include education as a priority in addition to ordnance clearance which has been Ireland's focus over the last 2 decades

Subject Matter: We spoke about foreign policy pertaining to Irish Aid support of Cambodia informing the DPO of our work in educational change and the need for a policy shift to include education as a priority in addition to ordnance clearance which has been Ireland's focus over the last 2 decades
Intended Results: We hope at some future point the Government of Ireland would have a policy to support education in Cambodia::It would be wonderful if an Irish embassy was opened in Cambodia

Lobbyist Name: National Federation of Voluntary Service Providers Supporting People with Intellectual Disability
Specific Details: Transparency of Disability Budget Announcements
DPOs Lobbied: Ged Nash|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Colm Brophy|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Bernard Durkan|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Transparency of Disability Budget Announcements
Intended Results: Transparency of Disability Budget Announcements
Lobbying Activities: 16th Jan 2024 - Email sent by Emer Costello (Oirechtas Disability Group Member) to Ged Nash, Bernard Durkan and Colm Brophy in their capacity as members of the Budgetary Oversight Committee. This email requested that they raise the issue of transparency at the Budgetary Oversight Committee and seek to ensure that future budgets contain clear and transparent information that can be fully understood by people with disabilities and the organisations that provide services to them. |Email|2-5

Specific Details: Communication to Budgetary Oversight Committee on behalf of Oireachtas Disablity Committee to ensure greater transparency in Health/Disability Budget Announcement
DPOs Lobbied: Ged Nash|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Bernard Durkan|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Colm Brophy|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Communication to Budgetary Oversight Committee on behalf of Oireachtas Disablity Committee to ensure greater transparency in Health/Disability Budget Announcement
Intended Results: Requesting Budgetary Oversight Committee to address the issue to ensure greater transparency in budgetary announcements so that people with disabilities and disability organisations can determine full impact of budgetary announcements
Lobbying Activities: Email highlighting that three months after Budget announcement there was still no clarity on Budget allocations for disability services which makes it incredibly difficult for Disability Service Providers, and particularly S39 organisations, to plan services for the coming year. |Email|1
